instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS? This power rail is PPBUS_G3H after going through a current sense resistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H & the input of PPBUS_G3H to circuitry that provides power for the CPU..
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP1V05_SUS: What is PP1V05_SUS? The PP1V05_SUS signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that supplies 1.05 volts, typically used in a suspended (SUS) state of the laptop. This state is a low-power mode where essential system functions are maintained, but the majority of the system is powered down..
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS: What is PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS? This is PPBUS_G3H after passing through a current sense resistor that splits it off from the rest of PPBUS_G3H. The purpose of this is so that we can measure how much current is flowing to this part of the machine..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.PP1V5_S3RS0: What is PP1V5_S3RS0? PP1V5_S3RS0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green and orange light but wont turn on
threads.message: got in a 2936 with a green light and orange light with battery in, but no fan spin and wont power up.  also the fan spins with a smc bypass.  i will test all the rails to see if anything is missing, it is a heavily liquid damaged board.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green and orange light but wont turn on
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_SW_T29BST</SIGNAL> -.34v

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING_ISNS</SIGNAL>   - 12.57v

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_OTHER_ISNS</SIGNAL> -12.57v

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> -18.87v

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.48v

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> - 5.03v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL> - 5.03v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> - 5.03v

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> - 5.03v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> - 3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> - 3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> - 3.32v

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> - 3.31v

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> -1.8v

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3</SIGNAL> -1.5v

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3RS0</SIGNAL> -1.5v

<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> -1.5v

<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL> -.75v

<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL> -0v

<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> -.90v

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_SUS</SIGNAL> -1.06v

<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> -.04v
(.026v to gnd in diode mode)

it appears <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is not present.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green and orange light but wont turn on
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green and orange light but wont turn on
threads.message: .342v to gnd in diode mode on <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL>. i do have 1.5v there also.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green and orange light but wont turn on
threads.message:
I guess it was a typo, maybe Duke is asking for resistance on the missing voltage rail.............

CPUVCCIOS0_EN present????

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green and orange light but wont turn on
threads.message:
Well if that is the case i have the resistance listed 
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> -.04v
(.026v to gnd in diode mode)

Yes CPUVCCIOS0_EN is 3.24v on pin 3 of the  <CHIP>U7600</CHIP>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green and orange light but wont turn on
threads.message: ok resistance is not the same as diode mode!!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green and orange light but wont turn on
threads.message: Enable is there and there seems to be no short, I will let you decide what could be the problem.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green and orange light but wont turn on
threads.message: okay replaced the <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> and everything's working. (solved)
